last_post.content:
I feel climate grief every day, along with sadness and shame about the loss of biodiversity, the ongoing sixth mass extinction, and the crushing of hopes and dreams for our young people.

Of course, I'm not alone in these feelings. But here is an article offering good advice for dealing with the stress of eco-awareness...
___________________________

Burning forests, starving polar bears, and poisoned fish. It's all so heartbreaking and right now seems to be part of the daily news cycle. For some, the constant reminders of environmental destruction have a psychological impact.

“I feel considerable guilt and despair surrounding the climate crisis,” says Konrad Juengling, a 34-year-old LGBT activist, and writer from Portland, Oregon. He says climate change is something he worries about almost daily — from plastic packaging at the grocery store to melting glaciers and rising sea levels. “The more I learn about the climate crisis, the more depressing it is.”

Juengling’s sentiments aren't unique. People all around the globe are mourning a changing planet and feeling depressed about global warming — especially Millennials and Gen Zers.

The term “ecological grief” was first used in a 2018 paper where it was described as a response to the loss of cherished species, ecosystems, and landscapes due to climate change. The authors of that report researched the emotional impact of disappearing land due to climate change through the lived experience of indigenous Inuit people in Canada and farmers in the Australian Wheatbelt.

Today psychologists use the term "climate grief" to refer to feelings of sadness, loss, and anxiety in response to climate devastation.

How common is climate grief? A 2019 poll by the American Psychological Association revealed that 68% of US adults are experiencing at least a little anxiety about climate change. And almost half (47%) of young respondents aged 18 to 34 said their anxiety about the climate was affecting their daily lives.
___________________________

FULL ARTICLE -- https://www.psycom.net/anxiety/coping-climate-grief-anxiety

last_post.content: Jane's Walk é um festival no qual são realizados passeios a pé em várias cidades do mundo. Inspirado na ativista Jane Jacobs, os passeios são realizados anualmente durante o primeiro final de semana de maio, no dia do seu aniversário. Os passeios podem ser propostos e conduzidos por qualquer pessoa que tenha interesse nos bairros onde vive, trabalha ou frequenta e visam explorar a história, cultura local e problemas enfrentados pelos moradores. Confira a programação: https://janeswalk.org/.

Meta claims that the Metaverse will contribute $45.3B to Canada's annual GDP by 2035.

title: A garden alive with art: all-natural insect sculptures – in pictures

last_post.content:
Montreal-based artist Raku Inoue used sticks, seeds and petals to create his Natura Insects series. “I think about the main shape of the insect,” he says, “and try to find something to satisfy that. It’s very much like a puzzle."

The series started as a morning routine over coffee to sharpen his thoughts for the day. “It was never meant to be a complex process, but rather an easygoing, morning mind-stretching exercise.”

David Slifka's chart actually doesn't tell the whole story.

Here's what more people need to see: the rise in *key apps.

Both #Misskey and #Calckey have seen major growth. What's notable is that it's largely occurred after February 2022 -- well after Mastodon's growth plateaued.

In fact, these charts don't even reflect what's happening right now. I know that Misskey alone now has over 300,000 accounts, and is now the 2nd most used platform on the Fediverse.

What's more, misskey.io just overtook mastodon.online, one of Mastodon gGmbh's flagship servers.

On the Calckey side, it's a similar story -- though we have yet to reach the heights of Misskey. The server that I admin, calckey.social, is having the most activity it's ever had right this moment.

Lots of Calckey servers are starting up right as we speak, and the enthusiasm cannot be denied.

This is why it serves to look at the Fediverse beyond Mastodon.

@fediversenews@venera.social

ICYMI, the CSS Zen Garden just turned 20.
https://elk.zone/tilde.zone/@daveshea/110337299027050269

I wanted to follow that up by talking about some of the designs it contains. I’ve intentionally stayed quiet about the decisions behind the ones I curated over the years and avoided showing preference, but it’s been 20 years now so what better time to share a few of my own favourites and reminisce over some of the untold back stories behind the site. I’ll be adding a new one daily for the next week or so. Some of my own will be on here — not because I think they’re particularly special, but because they have extra meaning to me.

But, I do I need to address this up front – there are no gender diverse or BIPOC people on the list, it’s a bunch of white guys. I know that sucks, it’s a reality of the 20 year old list I have to work with. At the time the industry and its contributions still unfortunately skewed heavily male. I wish I could go back and try harder to look for and encourage diverse contributors, but I had yet to properly learn about the problem then or how I should be part of the solution. I try much harder these days, but shamed to admit that I didn’t then.

With that, if you’re still with me, let’s get into it.

About the E. Jean Carroll rape case.

From @KlasfeldReports, the judge just told the jury:

"I emphasize to you that this is a civil case for damages. It is not a criminal case."

He notes that the first count asks the jury whether they find, by a preponderance of the evidence, that Trump raped her.

Juries can surprise us (a point I kept trying to hammer for the 'indictments = accountability" people) but preponderance of the evidence is a low standard.

See:
https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/preponderance_of_the_evidence
